bAMREx-w6.memHandModelNotes: Do NOT limit Coastal Plain or Piedmont floodplain/riparian MUs with flowing water buffer. NC-GAP used a 200 m buffer on wet veg, but I decided to let MUs determine habitat in swamps, bottomlands and other habitats with wet vegetation.   Blake and Karr (1984) report minimum tract size used in Maryland was 70 ha. Sherry et al. (1997) state "prefers large, intact tracts of habitat > 4000 ha." based on Robbins (1979), Ambuel and Temple (1983), and Robbins et al. (1989).

bAMREx-s5.memHandModelNotes: Do NOT limit Coastal Plain or Piedmont floodplain/riparian MUs with flowing water buffer. NC-GAP used a 200 m buffer on wet veg, but I decided to let MUs determine habitat in swamps, bottomlands and other habitats with wet vegetation.   Blake and Karr (1984) report minimum tract size used in Maryland was 70 ha. Sherry et al. (1997) state "prefers large, intact tracts of habitat > 4000 ha." based on Robbins (1979), Ambuel and Temple (1983), and Robbins et al. (1989).

references: Rappole, J.H., and D.W. Warner. 1980. Ecological aspects of migrant bird behavior in Veracruz, Mexico. Pages 353-393 in A. Keast and E.S. Morton, editors. Migrant birds in the neotropics:ecology, behavior, distribution, and conservation. Smithsonian Insti

Sherry, T.W., and R.T. Holmes. 1992. Population fluctuations in a long-distance neotropical migrant:demographic evidence for the importance of breeding season events in the American redstart. Pages 431-442 in J.M. Hagan III and D.W. Johnston, editors. Eco
Ligon, J.S. 1961. New Mexico birds and where to find them. The University of New Mexico Press, Albuquerque.

Robbins, C.S., B.A. Dowell, D.K. Dawson, J.A. Colon, R. Estrada, A. Sutton, R. Sutton, and D. Weyer. 1992. Comparison of Neotropical migrant landbird poulations wintering in tropical forest, isolated forest fragments, and agricultural habitats. Pages 207-
Pashley, D.N., and R.B. Hamilton. 1990. Warblers of the West Indies. III. The Lesser Antilles. Caribbean J. Sci. 26:75-97.
Cruickshank, A. D. 1979. American Redstart. Pages 139-41 in L. Griscom and A. Sprunt Jr. (editors). The Warblers of North America. Doubleday and Company, Inc., Garden City, New York.
Lynch, J. F. 1989. Distribution of overwintering Nearctic migrants in the Yucatan Peninsula, I:general patterns of occurrence. Condor 91:515-544.
Lefebvre, G., B. Poulin, and R. McNeil. 1992. Abundance, feeding behavior, and body condition of nearctic warblers wintering in Venezuelan mangroves. Wilson Bulletin 104:400-412.
Sliwa, A., and T. W. Sherry. 1992. Surveying wintering warbler populations in Jamaica:point counts with and without broadcast vocalizations. Condor 94:924-936.
Hagan, J.M., III, and D.W. Johnston, editors. 1992. Ecology and conservation of neotropical migrant landbirds. Smithsonian Institution Press, Washington, D.C. xiii + 609 pp.

Arizona Game and Fish Department 2002 Setophaga ruticilla. Unpublished abstract compiled and
edited by the Heritage Data Management System, Arizona Game and Fish Department, Phoenix,
AZ. 4pp.
Hayward, C.L., C. Cottom, A.M. Woodbury, and H.H. Frost. 1976. Birds of Utah. Great Basin Nature Memoirs No. 1. 229 pp.
Harrison, H.H. 1984. Wood warblers' world. Simon and Schuster, New York. 335 pp.

DeGraaf, R. M. 1985. Breeding bird assemblages in New England northern hardwoods. Pages 5-22 in R. J. Regan and D. E. Capen (editors). Conference Proceedings:The impact of timber management practices on nongame birds in Vermont. Montpellier, Vermont.

Robbins, C.S. 1979. Effect of forest fragmentation on bird populations. Pp. 198-212 in:R.M. DeGraff and K.E. Evans (ed.). Management of north central and northeastern forests for nongame birds. U.S. Dep. Agric. For. Serv., Gen. Tech. Rep. NC-51. 268pp.

Bent, A.C. 1953. Life histories of North American wood warblers. U.S. Natl. Mus. Bull. 203. Washington, D.C.

Holmes, R.T., and T.W. Sherry. 1992. Site fidelity of migratory warblers in temperate breeding and neotropical wintering areas:Implications for population dynamics, habitat selection, and conservaion. Pages 563-75 in J.M. Hagan III and D.W. Johnston, edit
Schrupp, D.L., and A. Cade 1989 Colorado Wildlife Species Database - User's Guide. Colorado Division of Wildlife. DOW-HR-01-89. Denver, CO.

Kingery, Hugh E. (ed). 1998. Colorado Breeding Bird Atlas Colorado Bird Atlas Project (CBAP) and
Colorado Division of Wildlife, Publishers.
Ryser, F.A. 1985. Birds of the Great Basin a natural history. University of Nevada Press, Reno.

Harrison, H.H. 1979. A field guide to western birds' nests. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston. 279 pp.
Hamel, P. B. 1992. The land manager's guide to the birds of the south. The Nature Conservancy, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 367 pp + several appendices.

habitat_description:
The American Redstart (Setophaga ruticilla) breeds across much of the northern and eastern US and southern Canada (Sherry and Holmes 1997). It winters in Baja, CA, central Florida, central Mexico south to Ecuador and Brazil (Sherry and Holmes 1997, Kingery 1998). In the southwest, the American Redstart breeds in northeastern Utah, south Apache County in east-central Arizona, and north-central Colorado (Phillips et al. 1964, Hayward et al. 1976, Sherry and Holmes 1997, Kingery 1998). It is an uncommon to common migrant throughout the southwest (Ligon 1961, Phillips et al. 1964, Hayward et al. 1976, Ryser 1985, Alcorn 1988, Andrews and Righter 1992, Kingery 1998). 

Generally regarded as a forest interior species, the redstart prefers moist, deciduous, second-growth woodlands with abundant shrubs during the breeding season (Sherry and Holmes 1997).  They are also found in shrubby second-growth woodlands, tree fall gaps in old-growth forest, orchards, and mixed-deciduous-coniferous woodlands.  Breeding also occurs in coniferous woodlands in the northern part of its range (Alberta and New Brunswick), but deciduous vegetation is preferred over coniferous vegetation in the northeastern United States (Sherry and Holmes 1997).   Redstarts are more commonly found near water in the southern and western parts of their range (Sherry and Holmes 1997).

In the Southeast, important forest communities include elm-ash-cottonwood, southern mixed mesic hardwoods, oak-gum-cypress, oak-hickory and cove hardwoods, and yellow birch.  In the Atlantic Piedmont and Coastal Plains, they favor bottomland hardwoods and swamps while in the Appalachians, they use more open riparian hardwood forests/woodlands and are less frequently encountered in medium-growth upland hardwoods (Hamel 1992).   

Breeding habitats for the American Redstart in western North America include willow (Salix spp.) and alder (Alnus spp.) thickets, riparian woodlands, and coniferous woodlands (Sherry and Holmes 1997). They prefer closed canopies, a dense mid and understory, and well-developed undergrowth (AGFD 2002). Redstarts are often associated with streamside habitats (Kingery 1998). Breeding sites in Colorado occur in lowland riparian areas dominated by woodlands of cottonwoods (Populus spp.) with understories of willows and alders (Kingery 1998, BISON-M).  

In Colorado, this species is common below 1,981m, but can occur up to 3,657m (Andrew and Righter 1992, Biota Information System of New Mexico, Schrupp and Cade 1989). In New Mexico, the American Redstart inhabits woodlands at elevations between 853-2,286m (BISON-M). In Arizona, this bird occupies habitats from 1,582- 2,245m in elevation (AGFD 2002).

American Redstarts appear to be sensitive to patch size in parts of eastern North America with a preference for patches >4,000 ha (Sherry and Holmes 1997).

Habitats utilized during migration include wider varieties of shrubby and wooded habitats, various forests, woodlands, scrublands, thickets, and agricultural fields (Sherry and Holmes 1997, AGFD 2002), but often consist of the much of the same habitat used during the breeding season.  

The majority of American Redstarts winter in the Carribean and Central and South America but some individuals winter in southern Florida and California.  A larger variety of habitats are used during winter than during the breeding season but they show an affinity for native forests and woodlands at low or middle elevations (up to 3,000 m in South America, up to 1,500 m in Jamaica).  They also inhabit mesic to dry forests, secondary growth and scrub thickets, and can be abundant in shade coffee plantations, mangroves, lowland secondary growth, and dry scrub (Sherry and Holmes 1997). N. Tarr, 29April10.
